title: Frankie's Yellow Pages
historical_context: This article is part of the Cow's Information Series and reflects the early days of telecommunications and phreaking culture, particularly focusing on the Bell System.
target_audience: Phreakers, telecommunications enthusiasts, and security professionals interested in historical telecom practices.
short_summary: Frankie's Yellow Pages serves as a comprehensive encyclopedia of Bell System terms, abbreviations, and acronyms, providing insights into the telecommunications industry of the late 1980s.
summary:
In 'Frankie's Yellow Pages', Franken Gibe presents an extensive glossary of telecommunications terminology, particularly focusing on the Bell System. This article is a treasure trove for phreakers and telecom enthusiasts, offering definitions and explanations of various terms such as 'Call Forwarding', 'Central Office', and 'Common Channel Interoffice Signaling'. The playful tone and informal style make the technical content accessible, while the detailed descriptions provide valuable insights into the workings of the telephone network during that era.

The article not only serves as a reference for understanding the jargon used in telecommunications but also highlights the cultural significance of these terms within the phreaking community. By documenting these terms, Gibe captures the essence of a time when telecommunications were rapidly evolving, and individuals were beginning to explore the boundaries of technology and access. This piece is a must-read for anyone interested in the history of hacking and telecommunications, as it encapsulates the spirit of curiosity and rebellion that characterized the early days of phreaking.
